verses.text: Seeing the crowds, He went up on the mountain. When He sat down, His disciples came to Him.
verses.comment: Jesus ascending the mountain echoes Moses at Sinai, suggesting Christ as the new lawgiver. His seated posture indicates rabbinic authority.

verses.text: He opened His mouth and taught them, saying:
verses.comment: The phrase 'opened His mouth' marks a solemn teaching moment, reminiscent of prophetic revelation.

verses.text: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
verses.comment: Poverty in spirit implies humility and total dependence on God. Entrance into the kingdom of heaven begins with spiritual humility.

verses.text: Blessed are those who mourn, for they shall be comforted.
verses.comment: Mourning here includes sorrow for sin. God promises consolation for those who grieve over brokenness.

verses.text: Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth.
verses.comment: Meekness reflects Christ’s gentleness and openness to God’s will, leading to future inheritance.

verses.text: Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they shall be satisfied.
verses.comment: Spiritual desire for righteousness is rewarded by God’s provision and fulfillment.

verses.text: Blessed are the merciful, for they shall receive mercy.
verses.comment: Mercy given is mercy received—an important principle in both divine and human relationship.

verses.text: Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.
verses.comment: Purity of heart indicates inner holiness that opens up encounter with God.

verses.text: Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God.
verses.comment: Peacemaking reflects the family likeness of God—acting as His children.

verses.text: Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness' sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
verses.comment: Endurance under persecution is a mark of genuine discipleship and the promise of the kingdom.

verses.text: Blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you, and falsely say all kinds of evil against you on account of Me.
verses.comment: Bearing suffering for Christ is a sign of union with Him; participating in His mission and suffering.

verses.text: Rejoice and be glad, for your reward is great in heaven. For so they persecuted the prophets who were before you.
verses.comment: Here Jesus aligns His followers with the prophets, connecting the old and new covenant witness.

verses.text: You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its taste, how shall it be made salty again? It is no longer good for anything except to be thrown out and trampled under people’s feet.
verses.comment: Salt symbolizes preservation and covenant faithfulness. Losing 'saltiness' implies loss of witness or fidelity.

verses.text: You are the light of the world. A city set on a hill cannot be hidden.
verses.comment: Light and city imagery calls believers to visible holiness that attracts others to God's truth and community.

verses.text: Nor do people light a lamp and put it under a basket, but on a stand, and it gives light to all in the house.
verses.comment: Christian witness is intended to be public, illuminating others and impacting society.

verses.text: So let your light shine before others, so that they may see your good works and give glory to your Father who is in heaven.
verses.comment: Good works are not for self-promotion, but to direct praise to God. The Fatherhood of God is highlighted.

verses.text: Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill them.
verses.comment: Jesus claims unique authority to 'fulfill' the whole Old Testament, showing His role as the Messiah predicted in Scripture.

verses.text: For truly I say to you, until heaven and earth pass away, not the smallest letter, not the least stroke of the pen, will by any means disappear from the Law until all is accomplished.
verses.comment: Jesus emphasizes the enduring authority of Scripture, reinforcing its divine origin and reliability.

verses.text: Therefore, whoever relaxes one of the least of these commandments and teaches others to do so will be called least in the kingdom of heaven; but whoever practices and teaches them will be called great in the kingdom of heaven.
verses.comment: Practicing and teaching divine commands is highly valued by God—implies a call to integrity and transmission of faith.

verses.text: For I tell you, unless your righteousness exceeds that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven.
verses.comment: Jesus calls for a deeper, inner righteousness beyond legalistic observance—aligns with transformation by grace.

verses.text: You have heard that it was said to those of old, 'You shall not murder; and whoever murders will be liable to judgment.'
verses.comment: Jesus cites the commandment on murder, beginning a series of teachings that deepen its spiritual meaning.

verses.text: But I say to you that everyone who is angry with his brother will be liable to judgment; whoever says, 'Raca,' will be accountable to the council; and whoever says, 'You fool,' will be liable to the hell of fire.
verses.comment: Jesus intensifies the Law by addressing inward attitudes and speech, showing His divine authority over moral law.

verses.text: So if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother has something against you,
verses.comment: True worship requires reconciliation—emphasizes the unity and holiness within the community.

verses.text: Leave your gift there before the altar and go. First be reconciled to your brother, and then come and offer your gift.
verses.comment: Reconciliation is prioritized before offering worship, pointing to the necessity of harmony in the believing community.

verses.text: Come to terms quickly with your accuser while you are on your way with him to court, lest the accuser hands you over to the judge, and the judge to the officer, and you be thrown into prison.
verses.comment: Urgent reconciliation prevents judgment—teaches wisdom for temporal and spiritual life.

verses.text: Truly I say to you, you will not get out until you have paid the last penny.
verses.comment: The image highlights the consequences of unresolved debts and disputes—sometimes interpreted spiritually regarding purification and forgiveness.

verses.text: You have heard that it was said, 'You shall not commit adultery.'
verses.comment: Jesus again cites the Decalogue, this time the command against adultery.

verses.text: But I say to you that everyone who looks at a woman with lustful intent has already committed adultery with her in his heart.
verses.comment: Jesus deepens morality, showing that sin begins in the heart—demonstrates His divine authority.

verses.text: If your right eye causes you to sin, tear it out and throw it away. For it is better that you lose one part of your body than for your whole body to be thrown into hell.
verses.comment: Hyperbolic language underscores the seriousness of sin and the cost of holiness.

verses.text: And if your right hand causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better that you lose one part of your body than for your whole body to go into hell.
verses.comment: Jesus reiterates the radical commitment to holiness, indicating the urgency of repentance.

verses.text: It was also said, 'Whoever divorces his wife, let him give her a certificate of divorce.'
verses.comment: Refers to Mosaic legislation: Jesus is about to clarify and intensify its meaning.

verses.text: But I say to you that everyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, makes her commit adultery; and whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.
verses.comment: Christ raises marital fidelity to a sacramental level, indicating lifelong union and gravity of divorce.

verses.text: Again, you have heard that it was said to those of old, 'You shall not swear falsely, but shall perform to the Lord what you have sworn.'
verses.comment: Jesus refers to Old Testament warnings against false oaths.

verses.text: But I say to you, do not swear at all, either by heaven, for it is the throne of God,
verses.comment: Christ surpasses old legal requirements, pointing towards reverence for God’s authority.

verses.text: nor by the earth, for it is His footstool, nor by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King.
verses.comment: All creation belongs to God; swearing by any of it invokes His authority.

verses.text: And do not swear by your head, for you cannot make one hair white or black.
verses.comment: God is sovereign even over our bodies; humility is called for.

verses.text: Let what you say be simply 'Yes' or 'No'; anything more than this comes from evil.
verses.comment: Sincerity and truthfulness are marks of Christian integrity—aligns with the call to holiness.

verses.text: You have heard that it was said, 'An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.'
verses.comment: The principle of lex talionis limited excessive retribution, but Jesus calls for a greater mercy.

verses.text: But I say to you, do not resist the one who is evil. But if anyone slaps you on the right cheek, turn to him the other also.
verses.comment: Radical non-retaliation reflects divine patience and the way of the kingdom.

verses.text: And if anyone wants to sue you and take your tunic, let him have your cloak as well.
verses.comment: Generosity in suffering reflects Christlike love—imitating Christ’s self-giving.

verses.text: And if anyone forces you to go one mile, go with him two miles.
verses.comment: Shows generosity in response to compulsion—practicing a greater righteousness.

verses.text: Give to the one who asks of you, and do not refuse the one who wants to borrow from you.
verses.comment: Spiritual generosity is a sign of Christian love and openness to God’s grace.

verses.text: You have heard that it was said, 'You shall love your neighbor and hate your enemy.'
verses.comment: Only the first part is scriptural; the second was a popular misapplication Jesus will correct.

verses.text: But I say to you, love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you,
verses.comment: Jesus calls for supernatural charity, showing the transformative power of divine love.

verses.text: so that you may be sons of your Father who is in heaven. For He makes His sun rise on the evil and on the good, and sends rain on the just and on the unjust.
verses.comment: God’s impartial generosity is the model for Christian love and sonship—links to the theme of family of God.

verses.text: For if you love those who love you, what reward do you have? Do not even the tax collectors do the same?
verses.comment: Genuine Christian charity surpasses natural affection—it is divinely inspired.

verses.text: And if you greet only your brothers, what more are you doing than others? Do not even the Gentiles do the same?
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts the limited love of society with the universal love He commands.

verses.text: Therefore, you must be perfect, as your heavenly Father is perfect.
verses.comment: Jesus sets the standard of divine perfection, inviting believers into a holiness that is complete and mature, not just external.
